title: Europe’s debt per person: over €50,000 in some countries
summary: A new Eurostat-based analysis reveals that national debt per citizen in several EU countries exceeds €50,000 — exposing a different side of Europe’s financial burden.
excerpt: A new Eurostat-based analysis reveals that national debt per citizen in several EU countries exceeds €50,000 — exposing a different side of Europe’s financial burden.

body:
By the EU Debt Map editorial team
Last updated: October 21, 2025

Introduction: When national debt becomes personal

We often hear about government debt in billions of euros or as a percentage of GDP. But what does that really mean for individuals?

A new analysis shows that if each EU country’s total public debt were divided equally among its citizens, some Europeans would face a personal bill exceeding €50,000 per person.

Why the debt-to-GDP ratio doesn’t tell the full story

The most common indicator — debt as a share of GDP — shows how large a country’s debt is relative to its economy. But it hides the scale of the debt per individual.

According to Eurostat’s Q1 2025 data, the familiar ranking looks like this:

  • Highest ratios: Greece (152.5%), Italy (137.9%), France (114.1%)
  • Lowest ratios: Estonia (24.1%), Luxembourg (26.1%), Ireland (38.8%)

The new lens: debt per person

Dividing total debt by population changes the story completely — revealing countries where individual burden is far higher than expected.

Top 5 EU countries by debt per person:

  1. Belgium – €52,952 per person
  2. Italy – €49,139 per person
  3. France – €46,545 per person
  4. Austria – €42,679 per person
  5. Finland – €42,234 per person

Countries like Belgium and Austria suddenly appear at the top, while ‘safe’ economies such as Ireland and Luxembourg rank unexpectedly high.

Hidden risks: wealth doesn’t mean immunity

The data highlights two distinct types of debt across Europe:

  • 1. The solvency pressure problem: Nations like Greece and Portugal, where smaller economies struggle to support heavy debt loads.
  • 2. The hidden burden problem: Wealthy countries such as Ireland, Austria, and the Netherlands, where debt looks manageable as a percentage of GDP but remains enormous in absolute terms.

In the long term, aging populations and rising interest rates could make these ‘hidden’ burdens more dangerous than they appear today.

Why it matters

Measuring debt per person makes the issue tangible. It shows the real financial promise every citizen inherits — not just economic abstractions.

Both perspectives are essential:

  • The debt-to-GDP ratio captures short-term crisis risk.
  • The debt-per-person metric reveals the scale of the long-term social and fiscal commitment.
